dt: {bc}to seize and take away by force

et: Middle English {it}rapen{/it} "to abduct a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}raper,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}rapiō, rapere{/it} "to seize and carry off, abduct a woman with of the intent of sexually assaulting her," going back to Latin, "to seize and carry off, take away by force, carry off a woman with the intent of sexually assaulting her, carry or sweep along, impel forcibly (to a course of conduct), snatch up, gather quickly" {ma}{mat|rapid:1|}{/ma}

The verb {it}rapen{/it} in its predominant modern sense is rare in Middle English, the more common verb meaning "to rape" being {it}ravisshen{/it} "to {et_link|ravish|ravish}." The {it}Middle English Dictionary{/it} lists {it}rapen{/it} with a meaning "to carry off, transport (the soul to heaven)," but all forms cited are for a past participle {it}rapt, rapte,{/it} which appears to have been borrowed directly from Medieval Latin {it}raptus,{/it} past participle of {it}rapere{/it} in this sense (see {et_link|rapt|rapt}). See also the note at {et_link|rape:1|rape:1}.
shortdef: to seize and take away by force

dt: {bc}rape of one person by several attackers in succession

shortdef: rape of one person by several attackers in succession
